SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5 "FOR THE YEARS 1883 to 1887 ONLY"

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name Robert Webster Widdess,
Present Address 509 - 1445 Marpole Avenue,
Pioneer Address Rocanville, Sask., 1883 to 1887.

Year you came to Saskatchewan 1883.

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? Five.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? Two.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Not very often.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? The neighbors usually came to see us on Sundays.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? When we went, which was seldom, it was usually for a week-end to one or other of our relatives.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? About

The was never any doubt/the welcome. Meals were taken for granted.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) No apologies were ever made that I know of.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? There was always a meal.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? The whole family went, but the place was looked after too.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes, these were all the order of the times.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

Every new arrival had a "Bee" to build his home. They were all built of logs. Sometimes they had bees to plow up the land too. Quilting bees were social events of great importance, and some times stretched out over several days interspersed with card games and dances.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. see above.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? There were no schedules.

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).

Applicable to this period (1883-1887) two N.M.M.Policemen arrived in our farm yard late one afternoon in 1886 with a prisoner from up around Fort Pelly and asked if they might stay for the night. Of course they could. They spread their blanket in the corner of our living room, pulled my mother's sewing machine over and handcuffed the prisoner to it. That was the only sewing machine for many miles in every direction. It may not have been the first to arrive, but of one thing we are certain, it was the first sewing machine to take part in law enforcement in Saskatchewan.

In 1886 Joseph Stocks arrived in our district with a large family of children and took up land about two miles east of our farm. He was a clever man, but he had some queer ideas. He had it all figured out how many acres were required for the upkeep of each person, and he planted grain accordingly. Then he started in the build a flour mill without metal of any kind in any part of the machinery. In place of nails or screws he used wooden pegs. All the wheels, cog-wheels and all, were wooden, and the wonder of it was, it worked. The kids started to come to our school. The bread they brought for their lunches was coal-black.

Applicable to this book of pages (or book of pages) of this book of pages if necessary.

In 1883 Joseph Stoks arrived in our district with a large family of children and took up land about two miles east of our farm. He was a clever man, but he had some queer ideas. He had it all figured out how many acres were required for the upkeep of each person, and he planned grain accordingly. In the build of each mill without metal of any kind in any part of the machinery, in place of nails or screws he used wooden pegs. All the wheel, cogwheels and all were wooden, and the wonder of it was, it worked. The kids started to come to our school. The bread they brought for their lunches was coal-black.
Mr Stocks had forgotten to clean the wheat before grinding it. The bread was much like the oil cakes we fed our calves, in appearance, but not nearly so pleasant to taste. Needless to say, he was one of the first to abandon the farm. But, the worst part of that was, he abandoned the family of small children too. My mother was largely responsible for the placement of them, and it turned out to a fine family. They all became splendid citizens.

BUSINESS AND SPECIAL INTERESTS

66. Do you have any collections such as stamps, coins, paintings, autographs, etc.? A fair collection of postage stamps, Canadian copper coins, etc., would be appreciated.

67. The stamp collection was started by me given to my son and came back to me under the terms of his will when he killed overseas in 1944. I am willing it to my grandson Robert Banting Widdess. The same is true about the coin collection.

No doubt, I became interested in coins because of my banking experience. And speaking of coins, in those early days we had York shillings which were half the value of a shilling. Several theorists tried to have the term "two bits" originated, have been paid here but I am still of the opinion that because it took two of the York shillings to make up a shilling, the expression "two bits" was coined.

68. These York shillings were silver of course, and were called bits on land. In 1904 or thereabouts, the silver was replaced by copper.

69. James McInnis, Moose Jaw, Sask.

Mint at Oleren, and was informed that copper coins had always been a girt with them up to Eaton's opening in Winnipeg, and that since then up to this time (1920) they had never been able to catch up with the demand.

70. And talking about banking in those early pioneer times, reminds me that in 1903 the bank authorized my signature on their currency notes. They send out the unsigned script in sheets of five each. During the grain marketing season, these small tickets arrived almost daily, because we had to pay for the grain tickets in cash. This meant, we had to sign up enough every night to take care of the next day's business. The signatures had to be written in India Ink and allowed to dry without blotting. In the small hours of the morning spread out to dry. Then find a newspaper officer open in order to correct numerical order, have them cut into bundles of a hundred bills each and be on deck to back into the vault, snatch a hour or so sleep and be on deck to start paying them out for wheat tickets by ten o'clock in the morning.

Now what do you think of that for a true "mankato" story?
